qas.question: What far-reaching result do scientists think has come about from symbiosis with bacteria?
What do all organelles have that is their own?
What has received more attention than other interactions such as predation or competition?
What eukaryotes create various sorts of bacteria?
What always depends on the cell for the process of division?

context: While historically, <b3_0>symbiosis<b3_0/> has received less attention than other interactions such as predation or competition, it is increasingly recognized as an important selective force behind evolution, with many species having a long history of interdependent co-evolution. In fact, <a0_0>the evolution of all eukaryotes<a0_0/> (<a1_0><b4_0>plants, animals, fungi, and protists<b4_0/><a1_0/>) is believed under the endosymbiotic theory to have resulted from a symbiosis between various sorts of bacteria. This theory is supported by certain <b5_0>organelles<b5_0/> dividing independently of the cell, and the observation that some organelles seem to have their own <b2_0>nucleic acid<b2_0/>.
